comment._content: @Fabricator of Useless Articles: I added the tag 'Zeiss'  because on one of the windows on the left there is an advertisement for Zeiss.

comment.author: 54075172@N00
comment._content:
It's that watchful eye that really makes this photo for me. It makes a comment about the photograph being taken, the witness that documents the events taking place. The event was posed for the camera lens to see. The eye also appears to judge the people in the image, as we might judge them too. 

The good guys are the ones holding guns and humiliating children. It's an interesting image that appears to be more than just a document.

comment.author: 82967752@N00
comment._content:
Interesting that you think they're children. They do look very young and vulnerable and they can't have been much more than teenagers, but these young women chose to sleep with soldiers of the occupation. I cannot know their reasons but sleeping with the enemy has always been an act of betrayal. 

The mother of someone I knew was a teenager in the Netherlands at the time. A Nazi soldier came to her father's door with a goat, and indicated he would exchange the goat for one of the daughters. The father said no and sent him on his way. The family was starving at the time, it was the Hungerwinter.

comment.author: 54075172@N00
comment._content: They look like children to me. Their size and the shoes the girls wear suggest they're children or at least very young adults. It seems an obvious assumption to see them as children. I'm not that naive to think children can't collaborate or commit atrocities. I think some situations are not as black and white as we think. This photograph raises questions. Who are these people? What did they do to bring them to this? What is justice and what is revenge? Why did they betray their friends and countrymen? Would I be in the crowd jeering? Human frailties brought on the Holocaust, what should vile murderers and collaborators look like? Why not scared children?

comment.author: 82967752@N00
comment._content:
They're all good questions. We're both looking at this from very different places, perspectives. 

Society has never set very consistent rules about when childhood ends and the age of responsibility starts.  In a superficial way young women in the 40's were treated much more as children.  Round about when this photo was taken my mother was 22 and attending interviews for her first job (in the UK)... wearing white socks and sandals and with her big sister as chaperone. At the same age in the late 70's I was wearing tights and killer heels and no one was chaperoning me.  

We would both have been held responsible and accountable for our sex lives from about 14 on.  As were the girls in the picture. Girls like these would have possibly picked a winner .. and got it wrong, or maybe just fallen for a good looking boy, or gone where the food and heat and warmth were. They would not have thought for a moment they were abused children, but maybe they were.  They would have known they were accountable to society.

Question: What is the boy in the middle holding aloft?

comment.author: 15646675@N08
comment._content: Lijkt inderdaad op de Lange Bisschopsstraat

comment.author: 31873461@N04
comment._content:
you would be surprised what people would do to gain extras in a time of scarcity. 
these women may have just been trying to support their families. and yet they also had the choice to say no. brings up an interesting question, what would you be willing to do if you had to??

as for the shaving of the heads, it was to single them out and shame them, the women had it easy, many of the male collaborators were beaten to death, or shot when the resistance took control.

comment.author: 18697358@N00
comment._content:
impossible to draw any conclusions about the girls or anyone else in the picture.!! Their shaved heads -  'prove' nothing about them  at all, what is this - trial by flickrpic?. 
They could have been wrongly accused, of whatever they were accused of  and brutalised - whether or not they had actually committed any 'offence'. 'Sleeping with the enemy' would most certainly seem to me to be less of a crime than letting someone starve,  Id probably do much 'worse' than that, to save someones life I cared about..I wouldnt have any respect for someone who tried to buy sex in such a way either, so would not make any effort to supply top quality service.

comment.author: 27686624@N07
comment._content: I can't stop thinking about this photo. Does the fact that someone was in the resistence automatically mean that they were good people? When I see this picture I would say no. There were good people on both sides, people who extended their hands to help somebody and said "stop" when  they saw something wrong. And there were bad people on both sides, too. I can understand the anger and fury of the people under occupation that had suffered and lost loved ones, but what they did to these women and children after the war is shameful. They should not have used their power in such a way - that was wrong. Shouldn't they have proved themselves to be better than that? When you humiliate someone you always dirt yourself.

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content:
A few things to consider.
Most of these women were punished by people who knew them, people from their neighbourhood, people who had experienced their behaviour for months, sometimes years.
Many girls who had German boyfriends were left alone by their neighbours, simply because they had behaved differently.
Please also remember that the Netherlands had several months of Hunger Winter at the end of the war.
While people were starving and dying in the streets these women often had a priviliged status, receiving help and food from the Germans.
This caused more hate then most romantic behaviour ever did.
Before the liberation many people expected the traitors to be publically lynched, in the end their punishment wasnt nearly as bad as people expected.
Many people dont look at this from the point of view from the people involved in punishing these girls and women.
Often their punishment wasnt just because of a little fling they had with Germans or a short romance, it was often based on behaviour that has been going on for a long time.
Yes often girls were punished just for falling in love with the enemy, often it was because of much more.

There were many different kinds of resistance, some were just there to keep control when the Germans left and the allies hadnt arrived yet.
Most of the kraut-girls were punished by angry mobs of civilians, most real resistance members were ordered to stay indoors during the liberation, many others were too busy to get involved with these kind of things.
In many cases the Resistance was there to actually guard the traitors from the mob.

Mof is a very old nickname for the Germans, not a very rude one.
Its origin is unclear but its been around for centuries, its means something like 'a noisy person, someone who shouts a lot'.

As for 'Black Book', its a fantasy movie that isnt very authentic (or good).

comment.author: 18697358@N00
comment._content:
It is impossible to be sure of  any justice or lack of it at the time - from the evidence of photographs like these - during and after the drawn out liberation that began in September 44, and went on until May 1945.
With the government displaced - initially in London, later in liberated Eindhoven - the military had to try to take control of the inevitable  purge of collaborators, without enough administrators, and thus obliged to work with the resistance... 
This was extremely difficult,  the resistance groups having the most  determination to see that the purge was carried out , were at the same time - driven by different political  or private motivations between different groups.  Nijmegen,  for example had 3 different mayors all appointed by opposing  groups - at the same time. Political feeling was inevitably channelled into the purge so that it became impossible for justice to flourish and the purge descended into chaos well before the end of the liberation in 45.
The young people in this photograph may simply have been pawns in the politics of the time.
We have absolutely no way of knowing.

comment.author: 8798197@N04
comment._content: first of all, i wonder how much of a hunger winter there was in Deventer. I don't think people were dying in the street there: in fact, people from the west of the Netherlands came to Deventer because food was more plentiful there. NSB membership in Deventer wasn't that high: appr. 400 people (1.4% of the population) Thirdly, the young people on the left side of the photo watching might be class mates, I realized. Also, it's true that many people "joined" the resistance after september 1944, when it became clear Germany would actually lose the war. These late recruits were called "september knights" (september ridders), and often they were the people forming the BS (Binnenlandse Strijdkrachten) who perpetrated these acts alleged against kraut girls and collaborators.

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content:
Deventer was heavy hit during the war, the hunterwinter may not have been as bad as it was in the big cities in the west but life surely was very difficult.
Daries talk of food shortages and lack of electricity.
Also only a day before this photo was taken the Twentol drama took place, where members of the resistance were executed only half an hour before the liberation of the city.
Many of the 'new' members of the resistance in 44 and 45 were those who actually joined the BS in 1940 but who didnt believe in resisting during the occupation.
Many people felt resistance was not a good idea because of the reprisals.
These people were mostly preparing for taking over control during and after the liberation.
Most of these acts were perpetrated by mobs, civilians, neighbours and indeed former class mates.

comment.author: 82967752@N00
comment._content: Because everything in Masoud's world is about him. The body builder is him. And what is important here is not the historically very interesting and complex picture but his analysis that it is a "great shot". It is not a great shot at all, except in the sense that the photographer was  there at a very specific moment in time, allowing us to witness that very intense moment. It's not about us or Masoud, it's about that very moment. Can you hear a crunching of gears when you look at the photo? I can. I think Masoud wishes he could.

comment.author: 26231703@N06
comment._content:
It's funny how this treatment of collaborators didn't happen in the contries that did some actual fighting against the Nazis: Poland, Russia, Jugoslavia, etc

I say it had something to do with making some individuals pay for a collective guilt, including the guilt of changing sides.

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content:
Most countries did some actual fighting against the Nazis, including the country where this photo was taken, the Netherlands.
And also in the countries you mention this kind of retribution happened.

comment.author: 82967752@N00
comment._content: Sometimes the countries that didn't field an army (or and effective army) had people who fought the hardest, dirtiest war. Try this for size. And the Dutch certainly fought, and in some ways are still fighting. I think the publication of this photo is maybe part of that fight. The treatment of collaborators, or those who were not seen to fight, or appeasers went on everywhere. To this day I'm not supposed to say my father was a consciencious objector, because there are still people alive to be upset by this. This is in the UK, my father signed up as a nurse in the RAMC instead once the white feathers and anonymous letters started coming through the letterbox. No one is suggesting the UK didn't fight.

comment.author: 26231703@N06
comment._content:
I'm not talking about the resistance in occupied contries, of course they fought against the Nazis. I'm talking about that in many occupied contries sometimes more people signed up for fighting with the Nazis on the Eastern front, than those who joined the resistance.
Things began to change after 1943 when Germany was clearly not going to win the war. 
I think that situation created a collective guilt which some had to pay for, - those who had clearly chosen (the wrong)  side.
I'm also saying that out of the ten largest battles in WWII, eight of them were fought on the Eastern Front, so I say that's where Hitler was defeated, but I am of course not saying that the British, French or Americans didn't fight Hitler, not  at all.

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content:
The Netherlands fought fiercely against the Germans in may 1940, some say it damaged the German luftwaffe so badly it influenced the entire war.
The Dutch could and should be proud of that fight.
The amount of people in the Dutch resistance was also bigger then those supporting the Nazis.
There may be some guilt but there shouldn't be.
More guilt was added later when people were influenced by political correctness and a unbalanced view of the war.

Countless things influenced the war, the was was won by the British when they stopped the Germans from invading the UK.
If that had happened the war would have been lost.
But yes, after that I agree that the Soviets sacrificed the most and were most important in defeating the nazis.

Let's just be glad Hitler WAS defeated :-)

The Soviets were not innocent of hatred. How many of their own people did they kill?


"Stalin's rule during the 1930s was based on fear and terror. No one was safe. Leading Bolshevik politicians, party officials of all ranks, scientists, generals in the Red Army, writers, teachers, factory managers, former members of the middle class, priests of the Orthodox Church, ordinary people - all were liable to be seized in the middle of the night, accused of made-up crimes, shot, left in prison for years without trial, or sent to a slow and lingering death in one of the country's many labour camps. It was not even necessary to have done or said anything that might be considered hostile to the government. Many people died having no idea why they were being punished.Estimates of up to 20 million people were killed."
